misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that performing a complete outer loop iteration (comparing all adjacent pairs) for each of n iterations will correctly sort the array, and that this nested loop structure is the standard way to implement sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While the student's bubble sort implementation is functionally correct (it will eventually sort the array), they may not understand that the outer loop should ideally have early termination when no swaps occur, or that the inner loop range should shrink with each iteration (j < n-1-i). The code works but is inefficient. More critically, this suggests the student may be implementing a memorized pattern rather than understanding the algorithm's logic. However, this is not a notional machine misconception per se—it's more of an algorithmic inefficiency.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The code produces correct output but uses O(n²) comparisons even in best cases where fewer would suffice.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student correctly believes that when swapping elements in one array (scores), they must also swap the corresponding elements in the parallel array (names) to maintain data integrity.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No gap here—this is correct reasoning and implementation.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Correct execution; names and scores remain properly paired after sorting.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the computer semantically partitions the input stream based on the printed prompts, expecting that all tokens entered after 'Enter names' will automatically be treated as Strings and all tokens after 'Enter scores' will be treated as integers, regardless of the actual order in which the user types them.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The computer's input stream is a continuous sequence of tokens. Java's Scanner does not 'know' which prompt was just displayed; it simply consumes the next available token in the buffer. If a user enters 'Alice 85' on one line, the code's separate loops for names and scores will fail.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array elements are not 'stable' enough to be directly evaluated within a conditional statement or that the computer requires array values to be extracted into local variables ('a' and 'b') to be 'active' for comparison and subsequent manipulation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java Notional Machine, an array access like z[j] is a valid expression that evaluates to a value. It can be used directly in comparisons and assignments without needing a local 'proxy' variable to hold the state.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the sorting process is somewhat probabilistic and needs to be repeated 'enough' times (exactly N passes) to ensure the array 'settles' into the correct order, rather than understanding the deterministic nature of each pass in a Bubble Sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student lacks a precise model of how the inner loop's execution affects the array state (i.e., that each pass guarantees one element moves to its final position), leading to an inefficient implementation that repeats the full search N times.
